info.description:
navitia.io is the open API for building cool stuff with mobility data. It provides the following services

    * journeys computation
    * line schedules
    * next departures
    * exploration of public transport data / search places
    * and sexy things such as isochrones

    navitia is a HATEOAS API that returns JSON formated results
info.title: navitia

parameters.description:
Date and time to go/arrive (see `datetime_represents`).
Note: the datetime must be in the coverage’s publication period.
parameters.name: datetime

parameters.description:
Determine how datetime is handled.

Possible values:
 * 'departure' - Compute journeys starting after datetime
 * 'arrival' - Compute journeys arriving before datetime
parameters.name: datetime_represents

parameters.description: Maximum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: max_nb_transfers

parameters.description: Minimum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: min_nb_transfers

parameters.description:
Force the first section mode if the first section is not a public transport one.
`bss` stands for bike sharing system.
Note 1: It’s an array, you can give multiple modes.
Note 2: Choosing `bss` implicitly allows the walking mode since you might have to walk to the bss station.
Note 3: The parameter is inclusive, not exclusive, so if you want to forbid a mode, you need to add all the other modes. Eg: If you never want to use a car, you need: `first_section_mode[]=walking&first_section_mode[]=bss&first_section_mode[]=bike&last_section_mode[]=walking&last_section_mode[]=bss&last_section_mode[]=bike`
parameters.name: first_section_mode[]

parameters.description: Same as first_section_mode but for the last section.
parameters.name: last_section_mode[]

parameters.description:
Maximum allowed duration to reach the public transport (same limit used before and after public transport).
Use this to limit the walking/biking part.
Unit is seconds
parameters.name: max_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of walking on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_walking_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bike on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bike_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bss on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bss_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of car on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_car_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of ridesharing on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_ridesharing_duration_to_pt

parameters.description:
Walking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: walking_speed

parameters.description:
Biking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bike_speed

parameters.description:
Speed while using a bike from a bike sharing system for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bss_speed

parameters.description:
Driving speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: car_speed

parameters.description:
ridesharing speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: ridesharing_speed

parameters.description:
If you want to avoid lines, modes, networks, etc.
Note: the forbidden_uris[] concern only the public transport objects. You can’t for example forbid the use of the bike with them, you have to set the fallback modes for this (first_section_mode[] and last_section_mode[])
parameters.name: forbidden_uris[]

parameters.description:
If you want to use only a small subset of the public transport objects in your solution.
Note: The constraint intersects with forbidden_uris[]. For example, if you ask for `allowed_id[]=line:A&forbidden_uris[]=physical_mode:Bus`, only vehicles of the line A that are not buses will be used.
parameters.name: allowed_id[]

parameters.description:
DEPRECATED, replaced by `data_freshness`.
If true the algorithm takes the disruptions into account, and thus avoid disrupted public transport.
Nota: `disruption_active=true` <=> `data_freshness=realtime`
parameters.name: disruption_active

parameters.description:
Define the freshness of data to use to compute journeys.
When using the following parameter `&data_freshness=base_schedule` you can get disrupted journeys in the response. You can then display the disruption message to the traveler and make a `realtime` request to get a new undisrupted solution.

Possible values:
 * 'base_schedule' - Use theoric schedule information
 * 'adapted_schedule' - Use of adapted schedule information (like strike adjusting, etc.). Prefer `realtime` for traveler information as it will also contain adapted information schedule.
 * 'realtime' - Use all realtime information
parameters.name: data_freshness

parameters.description:
Maximum duration of journeys in seconds (from `datetime` parameter).
More usefull when computing an isochrone (only `from` or `to` is provided).
On a classic journey (from-to), it will mostly speedup Navitia: You may have journeys a bit longer than that value (you would have to filter them).
parameters.name: max_duration

parameters.description:
If true the traveler is considered to be using a wheelchair, thus only accessible public transport are used.
Be warned: many data are currently too faint to provide acceptable answers with this parameter on.
parameters.name: wheelchair

parameters.description:
Define speeds and accessibility values for different kind of people.
Each profile also automatically determines appropriate first and last section modes to the covered area.
Note: this means that you might get car, bike, etc. fallback routes even if you set `forbidden_uris[]`!
You can overload all parameters (especially speeds, distances, first and last modes) by setting all of them specifically.
We advise that you don’t rely on the traveler_type’s fallback modes (`first_section_mode[]` and `last_section_mode[]`) and set them yourself.
parameters.name: traveler_type

parameters.description: Specify if direct path should be suggested
parameters.name: direct_path

parameters.description: Radius length (in meters) around the coordinates of departure in which the stop points are considered free to go (crowfly=0)
parameters.name: free_radius_from

parameters.description: Radius length (in meters) around the coordinates of arrival in which the stop points are considered free to go (crowfly=0)
parameters.name: free_radius_to

Note 3: The parameter is inclusive, not exclusive, so if you want to forbid a mode, you need to add all the other modes. Eg: If you never want to use a car, you need: `first_section_mode[]=walking&first_section_mode[]=bss&first_section_mode[]=bike&last_section_mode[]=walking&last_section_mode[]=bss&last_section_mode[]=bike`
parameters.name: first_section_mode[]

parameters.description: Same as first_section_mode but for the last section.
parameters.name: last_section_mode[]

parameters.description:
Maximum allowed duration to reach the public transport (same limit used before and after public transport).
Use this to limit the walking/biking part.
Unit is seconds
parameters.name: max_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of walking on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_walking_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bike on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bike_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bss on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bss_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of car on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_car_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of ridesharing on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_ridesharing_duration_to_pt

parameters.description:
Walking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: walking_speed

parameters.description:
Biking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bike_speed

parameters.description:
Speed while using a bike from a bike sharing system for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bss_speed

parameters.description:
Driving speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: car_speed

parameters.description:
ridesharing speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: ridesharing_speed

parameters.description:
If you want to avoid lines, modes, networks, etc.
Note: the forbidden_uris[] concern only the public transport objects. You can’t for example forbid the use of the bike with them, you have to set the fallback modes for this (first_section_mode[] and last_section_mode[])
parameters.name: forbidden_uris[]

parameters.description:
If you want to use only a small subset of the public transport objects in your solution.
Note: The constraint intersects with forbidden_uris[]. For example, if you ask for `allowed_id[]=line:A&forbidden_uris[]=physical_mode:Bus`, only vehicles of the line A that are not buses will be used.
parameters.name: allowed_id[]

parameters.description:
DEPRECATED, replaced by `data_freshness`.
If true the algorithm takes the disruptions into account, and thus avoid disrupted public transport.
Nota: `disruption_active=true` <=> `data_freshness=realtime`
parameters.name: disruption_active

parameters.description:
Define the freshness of data to use to compute journeys.
When using the following parameter `&data_freshness=base_schedule` you can get disrupted journeys in the response. You can then display the disruption message to the traveler and make a `realtime` request to get a new undisrupted solution.

Possible values:
 * 'base_schedule' - Use theoric schedule information
 * 'adapted_schedule' - Use of adapted schedule information (like strike adjusting, etc.). Prefer `realtime` for traveler information as it will also contain adapted information schedule.
 * 'realtime' - Use all realtime information
parameters.name: data_freshness

parameters.description:
Maximum duration of journeys in seconds (from `datetime` parameter).
More usefull when computing an isochrone (only `from` or `to` is provided).
On a classic journey (from-to), it will mostly speedup Navitia: You may have journeys a bit longer than that value (you would have to filter them).
parameters.name: max_duration

parameters.description:
If true the traveler is considered to be using a wheelchair, thus only accessible public transport are used.
Be warned: many data are currently too faint to provide acceptable answers with this parameter on.
parameters.name: wheelchair

parameters.description:
Define speeds and accessibility values for different kind of people.
Each profile also automatically determines appropriate first and last section modes to the covered area.
Note: this means that you might get car, bike, etc. fallback routes even if you set `forbidden_uris[]`!
You can overload all parameters (especially speeds, distances, first and last modes) by setting all of them specifically.
We advise that you don’t rely on the traveler_type’s fallback modes (`first_section_mode[]` and `last_section_mode[]`) and set them yourself.
parameters.name: traveler_type

parameters.description: Specify if direct path should be suggested
parameters.name: direct_path

parameters.description: Radius length (in meters) around the coordinates of departure in which the stop points are considered free to go (crowfly=0)
parameters.name: free_radius_from

parameters.description: Radius length (in meters) around the coordinates of arrival in which the stop points are considered free to go (crowfly=0)
parameters.name: free_radius_to

parameters.description: True when '/journeys' is called to computethe same journey schedules and it'll override some specific parameters
parameters.name: is_journey_schedules

parameters.description: Minimum number of different suggested journeys, must be >= 0
parameters.name: min_nb_journeys

parameters.description: Maximum number of different suggested journeys, must be > 0
parameters.name: max_nb_journeys

parameters.description: Show more information about the poi if it's available, for instance, show BSS/car park availability in the pois(BSS/car park) of response
parameters.name: add_poi_infos[]

parameters.description:
Minimum timeframe to search journeys.
For example 'timeframe_duration=3600' will search for all interesting journeys departing within the next hour.
Nota 1: Navitia can return journeys after that timeframe as it's actually a minimum.
Nota 2: 'max_nb_journeys' parameter has priority over 'timeframe_duration' parameter.
parameters.name: timeframe_duration

parameters.description: The id of the departure of your journey. If not provided an isochrone is computed.

parameters.name: to

parameters.description:
Date and time to go/arrive (see `datetime_represents`).
Note: the datetime must be in the coverage’s publication period.
parameters.name: datetime

parameters.description:
Determine how datetime is handled.

Possible values:
 * 'departure' - Compute journeys starting after datetime
 * 'arrival' - Compute journeys arriving before datetime
parameters.name: datetime_represents

parameters.description: Maximum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: max_nb_transfers

parameters.description: Minimum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: min_nb_transfers

parameters.description:
Force the first section mode if the first section is not a public transport one.
`bss` stands for bike sharing system.
Note 1: It’s an array, you can give multiple modes.
Note 2: Choosing `bss` implicitly allows the walking mode since you might have to walk to the bss station.
Note 3: The parameter is inclusive, not exclusive, so if you want to forbid a mode, you need to add all the other modes. Eg: If you never want to use a car, you need: `first_section_mode[]=walking&first_section_mode[]=bss&first_section_mode[]=bike&last_section_mode[]=walking&last_section_mode[]=bss&last_section_mode[]=bike`
parameters.name: first_section_mode[]

parameters.description: Same as first_section_mode but for the last section.
parameters.name: last_section_mode[]

parameters.description:
Maximum allowed duration to reach the public transport (same limit used before and after public transport).
Use this to limit the walking/biking part.
Unit is seconds
parameters.name: max_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of walking on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_walking_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bike on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bike_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bss on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bss_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of car on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_car_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of ridesharing on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_ridesharing_duration_to_pt

parameters.description:
Walking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: walking_speed

parameters.description:
Biking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bike_speed

parameters.description:
Speed while using a bike from a bike sharing system for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bss_speed

parameters.description:
Driving speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: car_speed

parameters.description:
ridesharing speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: ridesharing_speed

parameters.description:
If you want to avoid lines, modes, networks, etc.
Note: the forbidden_uris[] concern only the public transport objects. You can’t for example forbid the use of the bike with them, you have to set the fallback modes for this (first_section_mode[] and last_section_mode[])
parameters.name: forbidden_uris[]

parameters.description:
If you want to use only a small subset of the public transport objects in your solution.
Note: The constraint intersects with forbidden_uris[]. For example, if you ask for `allowed_id[]=line:A&forbidden_uris[]=physical_mode:Bus`, only vehicles of the line A that are not buses will be used.
parameters.name: allowed_id[]

parameters.description:
DEPRECATED, replaced by `data_freshness`.
If true the algorithm takes the disruptions into account, and thus avoid disrupted public transport.
Nota: `disruption_active=true` <=> `data_freshness=realtime`
parameters.name: disruption_active

parameters.description:
Define the freshness of data to use to compute journeys.
When using the following parameter `&data_freshness=base_schedule` you can get disrupted journeys in the response. You can then display the disruption message to the traveler and make a `realtime` request to get a new undisrupted solution.

Possible values:
 * 'base_schedule' - Use theoric schedule information
 * 'adapted_schedule' - Use of adapted schedule information (like strike adjusting, etc.). Prefer `realtime` for traveler information as it will also contain adapted information schedule.
 * 'realtime' - Use all realtime information
parameters.name: data_freshness

parameters.description:
Maximum duration of journeys in seconds (from `datetime` parameter).
More usefull when computing an isochrone (only `from` or `to` is provided).
On a classic journey (from-to), it will mostly speedup Navitia: You may have journeys a bit longer than that value (you would have to filter them).
parameters.name: max_duration

parameters.description:
If true the traveler is considered to be using a wheelchair, thus only accessible public transport are used.
Be warned: many data are currently too faint to provide acceptable answers with this parameter on.
parameters.name: wheelchair

parameters.description:
Define speeds and accessibility values for different kind of people.
Each profile also automatically determines appropriate first and last section modes to the covered area.
Note: this means that you might get car, bike, etc. fallback routes even if you set `forbidden_uris[]`!
You can overload all parameters (especially speeds, distances, first and last modes) by setting all of them specifically.
We advise that you don’t rely on the traveler_type’s fallback modes (`first_section_mode[]` and `last_section_mode[]`) and set them yourself.
parameters.name: traveler_type

parameters.description: Specify if direct path should be suggested
parameters.name: direct_path

parameters.description: Radius length (in meters) around the coordinates of departure in which the stop points are considered free to go (crowfly=0)
parameters.name: free_radius_from

parameters.description: Radius length (in meters) around the coordinates of arrival in which the stop points are considered free to go (crowfly=0)
parameters.name: free_radius_to

parameters.description: True when '/journeys' is called to computethe same journey schedules and it'll override some specific parameters
parameters.name: is_journey_schedules

parameters.description: Minimum number of different suggested journeys, must be >= 0
parameters.name: min_nb_journeys

parameters.description: Maximum number of different suggested journeys, must be > 0
parameters.name: max_nb_journeys

parameters.description: Show more information about the poi if it's available, for instance, show BSS/car park availability in the pois(BSS/car park) of response
parameters.name: add_poi_infos[]

parameters.description:
Minimum timeframe to search journeys.
For example 'timeframe_duration=3600' will search for all interesting journeys departing within the next hour.
Nota 1: Navitia can return journeys after that timeframe as it's actually a minimum.
Nota 2: 'max_nb_journeys' parameter has priority over 'timeframe_duration' parameter.
parameters.name: timeframe_duration

More usefull when computing an isochrone (only `from` or `to` is provided).
On a classic journey (from-to), it will mostly speedup Navitia: You may have journeys a bit longer than that value (you would have to filter them).
parameters.name: max_duration

parameters.description:
If true the traveler is considered to be using a wheelchair, thus only accessible public transport are used.
Be warned: many data are currently too faint to provide acceptable answers with this parameter on.
parameters.name: wheelchair

parameters.description:
Define speeds and accessibility values for different kind of people.
Each profile also automatically determines appropriate first and last section modes to the covered area.
Note: this means that you might get car, bike, etc. fallback routes even if you set `forbidden_uris[]`!
You can overload all parameters (especially speeds, distances, first and last modes) by setting all of them specifically.
We advise that you don’t rely on the traveler_type’s fallback modes (`first_section_mode[]` and `last_section_mode[]`) and set them yourself.
parameters.name: traveler_type

parameters.description:
Determine how datetime is handled.

Possible values:
 * 'departure' - Compute journeys starting after datetime
 * 'arrival' - Compute journeys arriving before datetime
parameters.name: datetime_represents

parameters.description: Maximum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: max_nb_transfers

parameters.description: Minimum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: min_nb_transfers

parameters.description:
Force the first section mode if the first section is not a public transport one.
`bss` stands for bike sharing system.
Note 1: It’s an array, you can give multiple modes.
Note 2: Choosing `bss` implicitly allows the walking mode since you might have to walk to the bss station.
Note 3: The parameter is inclusive, not exclusive, so if you want to forbid a mode, you need to add all the other modes. Eg: If you never want to use a car, you need: `first_section_mode[]=walking&first_section_mode[]=bss&first_section_mode[]=bike&last_section_mode[]=walking&last_section_mode[]=bss&last_section_mode[]=bike`
parameters.name: first_section_mode[]

parameters.description: Same as first_section_mode but for the last section.
parameters.name: last_section_mode[]

parameters.description:
Maximum allowed duration to reach the public transport (same limit used before and after public transport).
Use this to limit the walking/biking part.
Unit is seconds
parameters.name: max_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of walking on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_walking_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bike on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bike_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bss on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bss_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of car on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_car_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of ridesharing on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_ridesharing_duration_to_pt

parameters.description:
Walking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: walking_speed

parameters.description:
Biking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bike_speed

parameters.description:
Speed while using a bike from a bike sharing system for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bss_speed

parameters.description:
Driving speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: car_speed

parameters.description:
ridesharing speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: ridesharing_speed

parameters.description:
If you want to avoid lines, modes, networks, etc.
Note: the forbidden_uris[] concern only the public transport objects. You can’t for example forbid the use of the bike with them, you have to set the fallback modes for this (first_section_mode[] and last_section_mode[])
parameters.name: forbidden_uris[]

parameters.description:
If you want to use only a small subset of the public transport objects in your solution.
Note: The constraint intersects with forbidden_uris[]. For example, if you ask for `allowed_id[]=line:A&forbidden_uris[]=physical_mode:Bus`, only vehicles of the line A that are not buses will be used.
parameters.name: allowed_id[]

parameters.description:
DEPRECATED, replaced by `data_freshness`.
If true the algorithm takes the disruptions into account, and thus avoid disrupted public transport.
Nota: `disruption_active=true` <=> `data_freshness=realtime`
parameters.name: disruption_active

parameters.description:
Define the freshness of data to use to compute journeys.
When using the following parameter `&data_freshness=base_schedule` you can get disrupted journeys in the response. You can then display the disruption message to the traveler and make a `realtime` request to get a new undisrupted solution.

Possible values:
 * 'base_schedule' - Use theoric schedule information
 * 'adapted_schedule' - Use of adapted schedule information (like strike adjusting, etc.). Prefer `realtime` for traveler information as it will also contain adapted information schedule.
 * 'realtime' - Use all realtime information
parameters.name: data_freshness

parameters.description:
Maximum duration of journeys in seconds (from `datetime` parameter).
More usefull when computing an isochrone (only `from` or `to` is provided).
On a classic journey (from-to), it will mostly speedup Navitia: You may have journeys a bit longer than that value (you would have to filter them).

parameters.description:
Minimum timeframe to search journeys.
For example 'timeframe_duration=3600' will search for all interesting journeys departing within the next hour.
Nota 1: Navitia can return journeys after that timeframe as it's actually a minimum.
Nota 2: 'max_nb_journeys' parameter has priority over 'timeframe_duration' parameter.

parameters.description: The region you want to query
parameters.name: region

parameters.description: Id of the object you want to query
parameters.name: id

parameters.description: The id of the departure of your journey. If not provided an isochrone is computed.
parameters.name: from

parameters.description: The id of the arrival of your journey. If not provided an isochrone is computed.
parameters.name: to

parameters.description:
Date and time to go/arrive (see `datetime_represents`).
Note: the datetime must be in the coverage’s publication period.
parameters.name: datetime

parameters.description:
Determine how datetime is handled.

Possible values:
 * 'departure' - Compute journeys starting after datetime
 * 'arrival' - Compute journeys arriving before datetime
parameters.name: datetime_represents

parameters.description: Maximum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: max_nb_transfers

parameters.description: Minimum number of transfers in each journey
parameters.name: min_nb_transfers

parameters.description:
Force the first section mode if the first section is not a public transport one.
`bss` stands for bike sharing system.
Note 1: It’s an array, you can give multiple modes.
Note 2: Choosing `bss` implicitly allows the walking mode since you might have to walk to the bss station.
Note 3: The parameter is inclusive, not exclusive, so if you want to forbid a mode, you need to add all the other modes. Eg: If you never want to use a car, you need: `first_section_mode[]=walking&first_section_mode[]=bss&first_section_mode[]=bike&last_section_mode[]=walking&last_section_mode[]=bss&last_section_mode[]=bike`
parameters.name: first_section_mode[]

parameters.description: Same as first_section_mode but for the last section.
parameters.name: last_section_mode[]

parameters.description:
Maximum allowed duration to reach the public transport (same limit used before and after public transport).
Use this to limit the walking/biking part.
Unit is seconds
parameters.name: max_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of walking on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_walking_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bike on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bike_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of bss on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_bss_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of car on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_car_duration_to_pt

parameters.description: Maximal duration of ridesharing on public transport in second
parameters.name: max_ridesharing_duration_to_pt

parameters.description:
Walking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: walking_speed

parameters.description:
Biking speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bike_speed

parameters.description:
Speed while using a bike from a bike sharing system for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: bss_speed

parameters.description:
Driving speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: car_speed

parameters.description:
ridesharing speed for the fallback sections.
Speed unit must be in meter/second
parameters.name: ridesharing_speed

parameters.description:
If you want to avoid lines, modes, networks, etc.
Note: the forbidden_uris[] concern only the public transport objects. You can’t for example forbid the use of the bike with them, you have to set the fallback modes for this (first_section_mode[] and last_section_mode[])
parameters.name: forbidden_uris[]

parameters.description:
If you want to use only a small subset of the public transport objects in your solution.
Note: The constraint intersects with forbidden_uris[]. For example, if you ask for `allowed_id[]=line:A&forbidden_uris[]=physical_mode:Bus`, only vehicles of the line A that are not buses will be used.
parameters.name: allowed_id[]

parameters.description:
DEPRECATED, replaced by `data_freshness`.
If true the algorithm takes the disruptions into account, and thus avoid disrupted public transport.
Nota: `disruption_active=true` <=> `data_freshness=realtime`
parameters.name: disruption_active

parameters.description:
Define the freshness of data to use to compute journeys.
When using the following parameter `&data_freshness=base_schedule` you can get disrupted journeys in the response. You can then display the disruption message to the traveler and make a `realtime` request to get a new undisrupted solution.

Possible values:
 * 'base_schedule' - Use theoric schedule information
 * 'adapted_schedule' - Use of adapted schedule information (like strike adjusting, etc.). Prefer `realtime` for traveler information as it will also contain adapted information schedule.
 * 'realtime' - Use all realtime information
parameters.name: data_freshness

parameters.description:
Maximum duration of journeys in seconds (from `datetime` parameter).
More usefull when computing an isochrone (only `from` or `to` is provided).
On a classic journey (from-to), it will mostly speedup Navitia: You may have journeys a bit longer than that value (you would have to filter them).
parameters.name: max_duration

parameters.description:
If true the traveler is considered to be using a wheelchair, thus only accessible public transport are used.
Be warned: many data are currently too faint to provide acceptable answers with this parameter on.
parameters.name: wheelchair

parameters.description:
Define speeds and accessibility values for different kind of people.
Each profile also automatically determines appropriate first and last section modes to the covered area.
Note: this means that you might get car, bike, etc. fallback routes even if you set `forbidden_uris[]`!
You can overload all parameters (especially speeds, distances, first and last modes) by setting all of them specifically.
We advise that you don’t rely on the traveler_type’s fallback modes (`first_section_mode[]` and `last_section_mode[]`) and set them yourself.
